Multi-objective optimization of building HVAC operation: Advanced strategy using Koopman predictive control and deep learning Mohammadjavad Soleimani Writing – original draft Software Methodology Data curation a Fatemeh Negar Irani Writing – original draft Software Methodology Data curation a Meysam Yadegar Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Conceptualization a ⁎ Mohammadreza Davoodi Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization b a Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Qom University of Technology, Qom, Iran Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Qom University of Technology Qom Iran organization=Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering,addressline=Qom University of Technology, city=Qom, country=Iran b Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, The University of Memphis, Memphis, USA Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, The University of Memphis Memphis USA organization=Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering,addressline=The University of Memphis , city=Memphis, country=USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Predictive control is an effective method for addressing the increasing demand for heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems to operate with greater flexibility and efficiency. In this paper, the multi-objective problem of energy-efficient HVAC operation while tracking desired setpoints is addressed through an advanced control strategy, including a novel supervisory data-driven predictive control (DPC) and a local loop with a PI controller. The supervisory level is based on the integration of the DPC framework and the bilinear Koopman predictor. A deep neural network architecture is developed to realize the bilinear building thermal predictor. In addition, the integral input-to-state stability (iISS) constraint is enforced in the training procedure to obtain a global iISS control-oriented thermal predictor that enables the application of predictive control purely based on historical data. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated through the simulation of a three-zone office in the transient system simulation software (TRNSYS). The proposed control configuration is implemented using a coupled TRNSYS-MATLAB simulation framework. It has shown significant potential for keeping the desired environment in line with energy conservation. Furthermore, a comparison is conducted between the proposed approach, the conventional controller, and another recent DPC approach, which demonstrates the suggested method’s superiority. As a result, there is a growing focus on the thermal comfort of occupants in both commercial and residential places, which influences the corresponding energy consumption [2]. Building energy consumption accounts for approximately 40% of the entire world’s energy usage [3]. Consequently, the reduction of energy consumption in buildings is a pivotal measure in attaining sustainable energy requirements, both on a domestic and global scale. Heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems are among the most significant contributors to meeting the indoor thermal comfort requirements [4]. The influence of thermal comfort on HVAC power consumption has increased over the past few years, contrary to the trend of reducing energy demand in buildings. Therefore, it is necessary to improve existing HVAC control frameworks toward more effective and energy-efficient approaches. A wide range of control strategies have been devised for HVAC systems, which can be broadly categorized into two primary groups: traditional control strategies and advanced control strategies [5]. The first group includes sequence control with on/off control logic and process control with proportional, integral, and derivative (PID) control logic [6]. Even though conventional controllers are widely used and have acceptable capabilities, their high maintenance and low efficiency indicate that they are costly. Moreover, the tuning of these controllers for multi-input multi-output (MIMO) systems is often challenging and may even be infeasible [7]. On the other hand, with advancements in computational technology enabling data processing, storage, and transmission, there has been a growing interest in utilizing advanced control methods to enhance the energy efficiency of buildings [8]. In recent years, model predictive control (MPC) has acquired immense popularity among advanced HVAC control strategies due to its variety of advantages [7]. Therefore, numerous control structures based on the MPC were established for a variety of HVAC control problems, which can be primarily categorized into classical model-based predictive control and data-driven predictive control (DPC) [9]. In general, the MPC framework heavily relies on a suitably comprehensive thermal model of the target building to improve efficiency and guarantee adherence to constraint [10]. Therefore, the mathematical model of the building must be precise enough to forecast building dynamics and computationally efficient for real-time control and optimization [11]. However, in the classical MPC framework, the required predictors are obtained based on the principles of thermodynamics, using expensive excitation experiments, or a combination of both. Therefore, creating and maintaining such models is frequently thought to be too expensive to warrant investment, which is a challenge that might hinder the commercial use of MPC in buildings [12]. Moreover, the complex ventilation and heat transfer processes of HVAC systems result in time-varying nonlinear partial differential equations that are inappropriate for control and optimization. Hence, several other studies (e.g., [13–20]) have resorted to making simplified assumptions in order to facilitate modeling, even though these assumptions may not hold true in real-world scenarios. To mitigate these challenges, various DPC strategies have emerged in recent studies using only historical measurement data. In this regard, an artificial neural network (ANN)-based MPC framework is developed to achieve the desired thermal comfort level and energy savings in [21]. The branch and bound (BaB) method is used to solve the complex non-linear optimization problem for discrete MPC. In [22], a review of studies conducted between 2010 to 2016, on ANN-based MPC framework in buildings is provided and the best network after multiple iterations (BNMI) algorithm is suggested to determine the suitable ANN architecture. Then, the ANN-based models are used to implement a supervisory MPC for reducing the operating cost of the residential HVAC systems. Moreover, in [23] a DPC framework based on genetic algorithm (GA) is developed for cost-optimal building design integrated with the multi-objective DPC of HVAC. Additionally, in [24], a zone-level heating setpoint scheduler based on the combination of the ANN, GA, and MPC is presented that maintains thermal comfort inside the building while reducing energy consumption over the following 24 h. Furthermore, in [25], an integration of a bi-level energy-efficient occupancy profile optimization method and a demand-driven ANN-based DPC strategy is developed for institutional building energy efficiency. Moreover, in [26], an ANN-based DPC strategy is developed for energy savings and maintaining a comfortable visual and thermal environment in smart building. The prediction model is obtained through a configuration of a nonlinear autoregressive exogenous neural network (NARXNN). Furthermore, a DPC framework is applied to the cooling of a real apartment using a combination of random forest (RF) and linear regression in [27]. The work in [28] presented a multi-objective adaptive DPC framework to balance energy costs and thermal comfort using two ANN-based models to predict indoor dynamics and thermal comfort. Further, an ensembled multi-time-scale deep-learning-based adaptive MPC (EMA-MPC) framework is developed in [29]. A multi-objective optimization is used to maintain thermal comfort while optimizing energy efficiency by controlling automated windows in a naturally ventilated room. The work in [30] proposed an ANN-based DPC scheme for HVAC optimization in sport facilities. Two strategies of the suggested ANN-based MPC system are being examined for managing and optimizing the hall’s HVAC system’s operation in order to increase energy efficiency and interior air quality. In addition, a machine learning (ML)-based MPC optimization scheme is developed in [31]. This work aims at achieving energy conservation with acceptable indoor comfort in a residential building using four ML-based and nonlinear fitting-based sub-models employed in a predictive control framework. Moreover, a DPC framework based on a long-term hybrid deep learning prediction model for the operational optimization of off-grid operation of renewable building energy systems is proposed in [32]. The work in [33] presented a DPC strategy to minimize HVAC energy consumption while maintaining thermal comfort. This method relies on an autoregressive moving average with exogenous inputs (ARMAX) model and the physical equations of the system under some simplified assumptions. Moreover, in [34], based on masked neural networks and inspired by the structure of the physics-based model, a physics-informed short-term predictive model is proposed. The aforementioned study used a hierarchical DPC framework to reduce HVAC energy consumption while maintaining indoor air quality in the building. The summary of the aforementioned literature is provided in Table 1. Due to the bilinearity that exists in the nature of the HVAC dynamics [36], determining linear and time-invariant models for the building thermodynamics might lead to a model mismatch, which in turn affects the control performance [37]. This bilinearity arises because the computation of cooling and heating energy involves the multiplication of supply air mass flow rate and temperature [36]. On the other hand, the primary disadvantage associated with typical ANN-based methods is the nonlinearity of the resulting model. This would inevitably lead to the non-convexity of the optimization problem, resulting in lower scalability, as observed in [21–26,28,30–32,34]. Moreover, this often leads to time-consuming simulations to evaluate the controller’s performance [38]. Further, the method provided in [27] requires considerable computing load to obtain an online short-term predictive model. In addition, adaptive strategies require large computational reliability when the system has restrictions and constraints [5,28,29]. Furthermore, the large number of parameters that need to be theoretically adjusted in these approaches can pose practical challenges [5]. On the other hand, physics-informed-based methods, as in [33,34], require extensive expertise to develop a control-oriented model that might be challenging in practice. Considering the limitations of the aforementioned studies, the work in [39] suggested a linear model realization technique based on the Koopman operator to model the nonlinear behavior of predictive mean vote (PMV) index for a single space office. Nevertheless, this work just provided a linear Koopman model realization and did not employ it for the control scheme. Furthermore, the work in [40] used the Koopman modes to analyze a building model and obtain zoning approximation. In addition, the recent study in [35] presented a DPC strategy for residential buildings. Using the Koopman operator and the Hankel alternative view of the Koopman (HAVOK) algorithm, this method obtained a linear model on the basis of projected time-delay coordinates for the district heating system (DHS). However, it is not concerned with energy conservation and solely aims at tracking the desired temperature setpoint. This paper proposes a hierarchical control strategy consisting of a supervisory DPC configuration named deep bilinear Koopman predictive control (DBKPC) and a local loop with a PI controller. This strategy seeks to maintain a suitable indoor environment for occupants while ensuring the energy-efficient operation of the multi-zone HVAC system. The primary idea behind our proposed control configuration is to minimize the cooling load by maximizing the supply air temperature (SAT) while maintaining the zone temperature at the desired setpoint. To this end, the supervisory DBKPC strategy determines the control signal for each zone’s fan and the maximum SAT for the air handling unit (AHU). This strategy employs a control-oriented data-driven predictive thermal model based on the deep neural network (DNN) and bilinear Koopman model realization to forecast the target building dynamics. The proposed framework is purely data-driven and requires no prior knowledge of system dynamics. Also, despite many other methods as in [21,24], the proposed predictive model is interpretable and scalable which means this framework can be extended for large-scale HVAC systems thermal predictive model realization. Furthermore, to enhance the stability of the realized model, a constraint of input-to-state stability is enforced on the training algorithm, ensuring the realized model is integral input-to-state stable (iISS). Moreover, to guarantee the convexity of the control optimization problem, a linear approximation of the bilinear predictor within the prediction horizon is determined that enables the use of quadratic programming (quadprog) solver. Indeed, the bilinear thermal predictor ensures prediction reliability and precision, and it has greater precision than the locally linearized model. Also, the approximation within the prediction horizon guarantees convexity. This strategy has a superiority over considering a linear Koopman model from the beginning in that it considers changing the states in the bilinear term at the start of each prediction horizon, which results in higher precision [41]. This work also accounts for building disturbances, i.e., weather conditions and occupancy behavioral patterns. The DNN scheme proposed in the current study differs from our previous work in [42] in three key aspects. First, the work in [42] considers the ambient temperature as one of the system inputs and does not learn a disturbance matrix. In this case, the disturbance could not be decoupled from inputs since it affects the bilinear terms of the realized dynamics. However, in the current study, we determine the disturbance matrix through the network. Hence, the disturbance does not affect the dimension of the bilinear terms and results in less computation effort in control procedure. Moreover, in the current work the iISS constraint is incorporated into the learning structure to enhance the stability of the realized predictive model. In addition, in [42], the input–output data are the zones temperatures and the SAT of the AHU as states, the ambient temperature, the zones inlet air control signals, and the inlet water to cooling coil control signal as inputs. However, in this work, the input–output data consist of the zone temperatures as states, the control signal of the zones’ fan and the inverse of the SAT of the AHU as the inputs. Additionally, the ambient temperature is considered a known disturbance. The key features of this study can be summarized as 1. A global iISS bilinear control-oriented data-driven predictive model is developed using the proposed DNN structure for multi-zone HVAC systems. The iISS constraint is enforced on the training algorithm to improve the stability of the system. Also, in the suggested structure, the known disturbance matrix can be determined directly through the network. 2. The predictive control problem of the multi-zone HVAC system is addressed using the DBKPC method, which takes advantage of the interpretability and global features of the Koopman operator for DPC configuration. Besides, the linear approximation of the bilinear predictor in the prediction horizon leads to a convex optimization problem that enables the use of quadprog. Indeed, the proposed algorithm retains the reliability of the bilinear realization while ensuring the convexity of the optimization problem. 3. A novel hierarchical control configuration is proposed to ensure the energy-efficient operation of the HVAC system. The designed control scheme consists of the supervisory DBKPC and the local loop with a PI controller. The significant role of the DBKPC strategy in reducing energy consumption is to determine the maximum SAT at which the HVAC system can efficiently maintain the desired indoor environment. Furthermore, the occupancy behavioral pattern and solar radiation are considered unknown disturbances, while the ambient temperature is taken into account as a known disturbance. 4. A three-zone office building is simulated using TRNSYS and used for performance evaluation. Furthermore, a comparative analysis is presented between the proposed method, the traditional PI controller, and another recent DPC approach. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 provides a brief overview of the Koopman operator and predictive model realization using this operator. Section 3 begins by describing the under-studied multi-zone HVAC system and then continues by providing the problem configuration. Section 4 provides the deep neural bilinear predictive model and the hierarchical controller design and configuration. The effectiveness of the proposed DNN architecture and control configuration is evaluated and a comparative analysis is provided in Section 5. The advantages and limitations of the proposed method are discussed thoroughly in Section 6, and finally, some conclusions are drawn in Section 7. 2 Preliminaries 2.1 Koopman theory As B. O. Koopman proved in 1931, a nonlinear system’s evolution of states could be described using an operator with infinite dimensions in an infinite-dimensional space [43]. Consider a forced nonlinear dynamical system of the form (1) x ( k + 1 ) = F ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) ) , where x ( k ) ≜ [ x 1 ( k ) , … , x n ( k ) ] T ∈ X ⊂ R n , and u ( k ) ≜ [ u 1 ( k ) , … , u m ( k ) ] T ∈ U ⊂ R m are the system state and the control input vectors, respectively. Also, X , and U are compact subsets, and F : X × U → X denotes a continuously differentiable function that describes the nonlinear system’s flow map. Let F be a Hilbert space containing all square-integrable real-valued functions with compact domain X × U ⊂ R n × m . Components of F are called lifting functions. The Koopman operator K : F → F is an infinite linear operator that describes the evolution of every observable ϕ ∈ F along the system’s trajectories according to the following definition (2) K ϕ ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) ) ≜ ϕ ( F ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) ) ) . Due to the Koopman operator’s infinite dimensionality, developing a closed-form approximation of this operator is imperative for control motives. The extended dynamic mode decomposition (EDMD) is among the most frequently used methods for approximating the Koopman operator [44,45]. To obtain the approximated Koopman operator, a countable set of N linearly independent observables { ϕ i : X × U → R } i = 1 N is required for constructing the lifting function as (3) ϕ ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) ) ≜ [ ϕ 1 ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) ) , … , ϕ N ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) ) ] T . In addition, n s discrete measurements called snapshots represented as { ( u ( k ) , x ( k ) , x ( k + 1 ) ) } k = 1 n s should be collected satisfying (1). The optimal Koopman operator approximation is determined by solving the following least squares problem. (4) min K ̃ { ∑ k = 1 n s ∥ K ̃ ϕ ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) ) − ϕ ( x ( k + 1 ) , u ( k + 1 ) ) ∥ F 2 } , where ‖ ⋅ ‖ F represents the Frobenius norm. 2.2 Koopman-based bilinear predictive model The type of approximated model using the Koopman operator is dependent on the chosen observables [46]. For dynamics with a more complex structure, a bilinear predictive model can be realized by imposing a suitable structure on lifting function with N = M ( m + 1 ) + m observables as follows [47] (5) φ ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) ) ≜ z ( k ) u ( k ) ⊗ z ( k ) u ( k ) , where the symbol ⊗ represents the Kronecker product. The approximated operator can be obtained using measurement data, calculating the lifted states (5), and employing the EDMD method. The bilinear realization coefficients are embedded within the first M rows of the approximated matrix K ̃ 1 : M = A H 1 H 2 … H m B , where K ̃ ∈ R N × N , A ∈ R M × M , B ∈ R M × m , and H i ∈ R M × M , i = 1 , … , m . The bilinear predictor can be represented as follows (6) z ( k + 1 ) = A z ( k ) + B u ( k ) + H u ( k ) ⊗ z ( k ) , where H ≜ [ H 1 , … , H m ] ∈ R M × M m . Remark 1 Inclusion of the real system states in the lifted space is an easy technique to acquire C , i.e., φ x ( x ( k ) ) = x T ( k ) φ x , 1 ( x ( k ) ) ⋯ φ x , M − n ( x ( k ) ) T . Consequently, computing the output matrix is trivial, and the inverse mapping from the lifted space to the original space can be easily determined as (7) x ˆ ( k ) = C z ( k ) , where C = I n 0 n × M − n , x ˆ ( k ) is the approximated states, I n denotes an n-dimensional identity matrix, and 0 n × M − n is a zero matrix of dimension n × M − n . Remark 2 Bilinear model realizations offer certain computational advantages similar to linear Koopman models while also being more likely to exist for arbitrary dynamical systems. Moreover, bilinear models have the potential to provide more accurate representations with lower dimensionality compared to linear models. 3 System description and problem statement 3.1 Building structure and HVAC simulation The target building is a three-zone office building, shown in Fig. 1(a), assumed to be located in Kuwait, with a total floor area of 300 m 2 and a volume of 1200 m 3 , which includes three thermal zones A, B, and C. As illustrated in Fig. 1(b), there exist six large windows on the building’s exterior walls, resulting in a high impact of the outdoor environment on each thermal zone. The office is open from 07:00 to 18:00 on official business days (from Saturday through Wednesday), and between two and four occupants exist in each zone, as detailed in Table 2. 3.1.1 HVAC system The under-studied HVAC system in this work is a variable air volume (VAV)-based HVAC considered for cooling operation in the three-zone office building. This system is controlled using multiple proportional integral derivative (PID) controllers known as baseline controller. By regulating the inlet air flow rate of the corresponding zone and the inlet water flow rate to the cooling coil, the baseline controller maintains a constant outlet air temperature for the cooling coil while controlling the temperature of each zone. The schematic of the three-zone HVAC system configuration is depicted in Fig. 2(a). 3.1.2 Development of the HVAC simulation Due to the inherently complicated nature of the building system, building performance simulation plays an important role in evaluating and understanding a variety of building control strategies and energy efficiency measures. It has been proven that TRNSYS is a reliable research and development instrument for HVAC system simulation. With TRNSYS, a public library named thermal energy systems specialists (TESS) is established for HVAC development that is consistent with empirical data. This software’s modules are developed by thermal energy systems experts from the United States, leading to high precision and fidelity in TRNSYS models. In addition, this software employs component object method (COM) technology, which enables it to replicate the HVAC system to a large extent [48]. Herein, the under-studied three-zone HVAC system is developed using TRNSYS, as depicted in Fig. 2(b). Furthermore, the simulation details, including the modules utilized and their respective properties, are summarized in Table 2. 3.1.3 Disturbance description As stated previously, for building control applications, disturbances usually represent weather conditions (e.g., ambient temperatures, solar radiation) and occupancy behavioral patterns [49]. As shown in Table 2, building simulation in TRNSYS takes into account occupancy and internal loads, such as equipment and lighting, in accordance with ASHRAE handbook fundamentals [50]. Also, the weather forecast for Kuwait is based on historical data from OpenWeather [51]. This data is accessible for any given timestamp and is downloaded using the OpenWeather One Call 3.0 API. Then, it is parsed into the input format for the predictive thermal model. It should be noted that, since the ambient temperature could be reasonably well-predicted and measured with high accuracy, it is considered a known disturbance. In addition, solar radiation and occupancy behavioral patterns are taken into account as unknown disturbances. The outdoor environment parameters were applied to the simulation of the building using block Type 15 in the TRNSYS software. Moreover, since the mixed air consists of 50% fresh air and 50% return air, and due to the wide windows that considered for each zone, the ambient temperature and solar radiation have significant impacts on the indoor thermal environment. 3.2 Problem formulation The SAT of the AHU has a substantial impact on the overall energy consumption, accounting for a major fraction of the HVAC system’s energy usage [52]. This is because of the direct and proportional relationship between the cooling load and energy consumption [53], and the close interconnectedness between coil’s cooling load and SAT. The total amount of the coil’s cooling load within the AHU is necessary for energy analysis and can be determined using the following equation [54] (8) Q Total ≜ U h A h Δ T lmtd , where U h and A h denote the overall heat transfer coefficient and the heat transfer area, respectively. Also, Δ T lmtd is the logarithmic mean temperature difference defined as (9) Δ T lmtd ≜ Δ T 1 − Δ T 2 ln ( Δ T 1 Δ T 2 ) , where Δ T 1 ≜ T h,in − T c,out and Δ T 2 ≜ T h,out − T c,in . T h,in is the inlet hot air temperature (i.e., T mixed ), T c,out is the outlet cold air temperature (i.e., T AHU ), T h,out is the temperature of outlet hot fluid (outlet hot water from cooling coil), and T c,in is the inlet cold fluid temperature (the temperature of the chilled water, which is considered to be a constant value of 7 ∘ C in our system). By substituting these values in (8) and (9), it can be concluded that raising the AHU’s SAT results in decreasing the energy consumption in the HVAC system. With this idea in mind, the overarching goal of this work is to preserve the thermal comfort of occupants inline with an energy-efficient HVAC operation. This problem is formulated in two stages, including identifying the required predictive model and designing a supervisory predictive configuration. These stages are outlined in Problems I and II and will be addressed in next sections using the proposed method. Problem I Predictive Control-Oriented Model Realization Consider a VAV-based multi-zone HVAC system with n thermal zones, where the temperature of each zone is denoted by T i , i = 1 , … , n . By leveraging the potential of the Koopman operator, the problem is to identify a predictive thermal model as follows (10) z ( k + 1 ) = A z ( k ) + B u ( k ) + H u ( k ) ⊗ z ( k ) + E d ( k ) , x ˆ ( k ) = C z ( k ) , where x ˆ ( k ) is the approximation of x ( k ) ≜ [ T 1 ( k ) , … , T n ( k ) ] T ∈ X ⊂ R n , u ( k ) ≜ [ U 1 ( k ) , … , U n ( k ) , U SAT ( k ) ] T ∈ U ⊂ R m , d ( k ) ≜ T amb ∈ R denotes the known disturbance (i.e., the ambient temperature). Also, U i ( k ) , i = 1 , … , n , denotes the control signal of each zone’s fan, U SAT ( k ) ≜ 1 / T AHU , and E represents the disturbance matrix with compatible size. In addition, each fan’s control signal determines the percentage of its maximum rated speed, and the pump control signal determines the percentage of its maximum rated power. Problem II Designing Controller Configuration Considering the realized model (10), the problem is now to design a hierarchical control configuration, including two following layers: 1. A supervisory DPC strategy that determines the maximum SAT for the AHU and the control signal of each zone’s fan by solving the following optimization problem. (11) min u J = ∑ i = 0 N p − 1 e ( i ) T Q e ( i ) + Δ u ( i ) T R Δ Δ u ( i ) + u ( i ) T R u u ( i ) , s.t. z ( i + 1 ) = A z ( i ) + B u ( i ) + H u ( i ) ⊗ z ( i ) + E d ( i ) , x ˆ ( i ) = C z ( i ) , u min < u ( i ) < u max , Δ u min < Δ u ( i ) < Δ u max , z ( 0 ) = φ ( x ( k ) ) , where e ( k ) ≜ x ˆ ( k ) − r ( k ) denotes the error, r ( k ) = [ T ref A T ref B T ref C ] T is the reference vector, x ˆ ( k ) = [ T A T B T C ] T is the system output vector, and N p is the prediction horizon. Also, u ( i ) = [ U A U B U C U SAT ] T is the input variable vector that U SAT = 1 / T ref AHU . In addition, Q ∈ R n × n , R Δ ∈ Q m × m , and R u ∈ Q m × m are symmetric and positive definite weighting matrices. These weighting matrices determine the relative importance of different terms in the cost function. The constraints on the input variable are considered by u min , u max , Δ u min , and Δ u max , representing input and input rate constraints, respectively. Minimizing the term e ( i ) T Q e ( i ) in the cost function primarily focuses on minimizing the tracking error and maintaining desired setpoints. The term Δ u ( i ) T R Δ Δ u ( i ) is associated with the input rate, and minimizing this term is essential to prevent abrupt changes in the input. Additionally, the term u ( i ) T R u u ( i ) is associated with minimizing the magnitude of control inputs. 2. A local PID controller that regulates the SAT of the AHU regarding the given setpoint from supervisory DPC. In fact, it can be deduced from (8) and (9) that the total amount of the cooling load depends on the T AHU . Therefore, this work seeks to optimize the HVAC cooling operation by maximizing the AHU’s SAT while maintaining the desired thermal environment. This can be achieved by addressing Problems I and II. Remark 3 In the cooling operation, a lower temperature setpoint can be tracked by reducing the SAT or increasing the control signal of the fan. Since the AHU is responsible for the main portion of the HVAC energy consumption and the fan’s electrical energy usage is significantly less than the AHU’s cooling load [55], the weighting matrices should be altered to prioritize the minimization of the U SAT ( k ) (i.e., maximization of the T AHU ). 4 Methodology This section presents the DNN framework proposed for identifying the bilinear predictive model, followed by the designing hierarchical control configuration. The entire procedure of the proposed framework is demonstrated in Fig. 3. In addition, performance evaluation metrics are described. 4.1 Bilinear predictive model realization As mentioned before, using EDMD to generate the approximated Koopman operator necessitates an appropriate selection of observable functions for discovering an intrinsic coordinate that remains invariant under the operator K ̃ [56]. However, one of the main obstacles that limit the scope of these approaches is that their performance depends heavily on the choice of observable functions over which the Koopman operator is to be approximated [57]. The selection of the observable functions can be based on system expertise (i.e., feature engineering) or a more general basis of functions, including monomials of the state up to a certain degree. Choosing dictionary functions is an active field of investigation in Koopman-based learning methods. To overcome this challenge, a DNN scheme is developed to investigate a suitable Koopman basis as well as the bilinear predictive model of form (10) simultaneously. In addition, determining the basis functions using the DNN framework could frequently lead to lower-dimensional predictors without the need for system dynamics. The proposed DNN structure shown in Fig. 4, consists of a linear layer called K ̃ and a deep part named lifting encoder and represented as G . The linear layer represents the approximated Koopman operator K ̃ , which is decomposed into the bilinear predictor matrices A , B , H , and E . The lifting encoder G generates the lifted states, which are then concatenated with the original states to form the z ( k ; θ ) ∈ R M as (12) z ( k ; θ ) ≜ x ( k ) G ( x ( k ) ; θ ) , where θ represents the network’s trainable parameters, i.e., weights and biases, M = n + n o , and n o represents the number of neurons in the encoder’s output layer. Then, the Kronecker product of the control inputs and the state-dependent observables is determined as u ( k ) ⊗ z ( k ; θ ) ∈ R M m . The proposed framework does not required an encoder in order to obtain the inverse mapping from lifted states to original states because the concatenation of system states with observables guarantees their bilinear evolution. Therefore, matrix C can be expressed as (7). In addition, the proposed deep Koopman approach is employed to model the effect of the disturbance on the dynamics of the system through the learning of the disturbance matrix E . To this end, having the norm-bounded disturbance d ( k ) ∈ R g , the disturbance matrix E can be learned by constructing the φ ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) , d ( k ) ) ∈ R N , N = M ( m + 1 ) + m + g as follows (13) φ ( x ( k ) , u ( k ) , d ( k ) ) ≜ z ( k ) u ( k ) ⊗ z ( k ) u ( k ) d ( k ) . The activations y ̄ l ∈ R n l of the deep part of the network at any hidden processing layer l can be expressed as (14) y ̄ l = Υ ( ϱ l x ̄ + b l ) , l = 1 , … , L , where x ̄ ∈ R n l − 1 , ϱ l ∈ R n l × n l − 1 , and b l ∈ R n l denote the input to layer, the weights matrix, and the bias of the layer l , respectively. Also, Υ represents the activation function, n l is the hidden layer’s width, and L denotes the total number of layers. The bilinear predictor is considered as a solution to the following minimization (15) min A , B , H , θ ∥ z ( k + 1 ; θ ) − A z ( k , θ ) − H u ( k ) ⊗ z ( k ; θ ) − B u ( k ) − E d ( k ) | | F . Due to the non-convex nature of (15), the training dataset D = { x ( k ) , y ( k ) , u ( k ) , d ( k ) } k = 1 n s has been portioned into two parts D = { D a , D b } , and the training process includes three phases that are conducted iteratively as described in Algorithm 1. In addition, a model selection according to long-term prediction is conducted in order to choose the predictor with the highest prediction performance on the test dataset. D t = { x ( k ) , y ( k ) , u ( k ) , d ( k ) } k = 1 n t , where n t denotes the number of snapshots for test. Next, this model will be used for the control scheme in the subsequent section. For stable systems, the obtained predictor via (15) may occasionally be unstable as a result of the perturbation in the training dataset, which is not ideal for making long-term predictions. On the other hand, since input-to-state stability cannot generally be expected for bilinear systems, variants such as integral input-to-state stability were introduced [58]. Hence, an iISS constraint is imposed on the training algorithm to improve the stability of the obtained bilinear model realization. Additionally, it is worth noting that for a finite-dimensional bilinear system, the iISS property is equivalent to the stability (Hurwitz property) of the matrix A , as stated in [58]. Next lemma is used to parameterize A , thereby ensuring that the realized bilinear model is iISS. Lemma 1 [59] Consider the parametric matrix A ( α , β ) ∈ R M × M as (16) A ( α , β ) = 2 ( χ 11 + χ 22 + β − β T ) − 1 χ 21 , where (17) χ ≜ χ 11 χ 12 χ 21 χ 22 = α α T + ɛ I , and ɛ is an small positive constant. Then for any real-valued α ∈ R 2 M × 2 M and β ∈ R M × M , A = A ( α , β ) is Hurwitz. Based on Lemma 1, the cost function (15) is modified as follows to guarantee the iISS property (18) min α , β , B , θ ∥ z ( k + 1 ; θ ) − A ( α , β ) z ( k ; θ ) − H u ( k ) ⊗ z ( k ; θ ) − B u ( k ) − E d ( k ) | | F . 4.2 Model realization performance metrics The prediction performance of data-driven methods is evaluated using various accuracy metrics. In this study, the coefficient of variation root mean square error (CVRMSE) and the normalized mean bias error (NMBE) are selected to evaluate the predictive model’s precision as follows (19) CV RMSE = 1 N s ∑ k = 1 N s ( x ˆ ( k ) − x ( k ) ) 2 x ̄ × 100 , (20) NMBE = 1 N s ∑ k = 1 N s | x ˆ ( k ) − x ( k ) | x ̄ × 100 , where x ˆ ( k ) and x ( k ) are the predicted value and the actual value at step k , respectively. Also, x ̄ denotes the average of the actual value over the considered time frame, and N s is the total number of samples. In addition, a Taylor diagram is employed to assess the predictor’s accuracy. This diagram is one of the most efficient methods for summarizing multiple prediction model evaluation indices, including the centered root mean squared error (RMSE), correlation coefficient values, and standard deviation [60]. The Taylor diagram consists of a polar coordinate system where the actual dataset and prediction models are represented by a set of points on the circumference of the circle. In this diagram, the azimuth angle of each point represents the correlation coefficient between the measured and predicted values, while its radial distance from the origin determines the standard deviation, and the centered RMSE is demonstrated by the distance from the reference point. The best predictor corresponds to the point that has the minimum distance from the actual data point. 4.3 Controller design This section describes the proposed hierarchical control algorithm for maintaining the desired thermal environment of the target three-zone building. The designed control framework provided in Algorithm 2 includes the required supervisory control strategy in Problem II that determines the control signal of each zone’s fan as well as the maximum reference for the SAT of the AHU. The latter is calculated as T ref AHU = 1 / U SAT ( k ) , and fed into a PI controller as a reference to regulate the T AHU . An overview of the proposed hierarchical control configuration is shown in Fig. 5. In this paper, a supervisory control strategy referred to as DBKPC is suggested for the hierarchical structure outlined in Problem II. This strategy employs the realized bilinear predictor (10) to anticipate the future of the system over a finite prediction horizon. An overview of the proposed framework is demonstrated in Fig. 3, which consists of an offline model realization stage and the real-time control stage. In addition, the DBKPC algorithm ensures integral action using velocity-form matrices [61]. The velocity-form can be extended for the realized bilinear system as follows (21) ζ ( k + 1 ) = A ζ ζ ( k ) + B ζ Δu ( k ) + H ζ Δu ( k ) ⊗ ζ ( k ) + E ζ Δd ( k ) , e ( k ) = C ζ ζ ( k ) , where ζ ( k ) ≜ Δ z ( k ) T e ( k ) T T and e ( k ) ≜ y ( k ) − r ( k ) represent the augmented lifted states and the tracking error, respectively. Also, Δ z ( k ) ≜ z ( k ) − z ( k − 1 ) denotes the changing rate of the lifted states, and r ( k ) represents the desired output. In addition, the corresponding matrices of the augmented system are defined as follows (22) A ζ ≜ A 0 M × n C A I n , B ζ ≜ B C B , H ζ , i ≜ H i 0 M × n C H i I n , i = 1 , 2 , … , m , E ζ ≜ E C E , C ζ ≜ 0 n × M I n . By considering Eqs. (21) and (22), Eq. (11) can be reformulated as follows (23) min u J = ∑ i = 0 N p − 1 e ( i ) T Q e ( i ) + Δu ( i ) T R Δ Δu ( i ) + u ( i ) T R u u ( i ) , s.t. ζ ( i + 1 ) = A ζ ζ ( i ) + B ζ Δu ( i ) + H ζ Δu ( i ) ⊗ ζ ( i ) + E ζ Δd ( i ) , e ( i ) = C ζ ζ ( i ) , u min < u ( i ) < u max , Δu min < Δu ( i ) < Δu max , ζ ( 0 ) = z ( 0 ) T e ( 0 ) T T , z ( 0 ) = φ ( x ( k ) ) . As mentioned before, the realized bilinear thermal predictor has the fidelity and reliability to forecast the system’s behavior. However, the convexity of the optimization problem could not be guaranteed using this model. Therefore, to ensure convexity, a linear approximation of the bilinear predictor can be used by fixing the value of the ζ ( i ) in the bilinear terms over the prediction horizon, N p . The resulting linear dynamics approximate the behavior of the bilinear realization in a neighborhood of the initial augmented lifted states ζ ( 0 ) and are represented as follows (24) ζ ( i + 1 ) = A ζ ζ ( i ) + B ζ Δu ( i ) + H ζ Δu ( i ) ⊗ ζ ( 0 ) + E ζ Δd ( i ) , = A ζ ζ ( i ) + ( B ζ + H ζ , 1 H ζ , 2 ⋯ H ζ , m ζ ( 0 ) ) Δu ( i ) + E ζ Δd ( i ) . Using the linear dynamics constraints, the convexity is guaranteed, and there exists a singular globally optimal solution that can be efficiently computed [62–64]. Since the resulting linear dynamics approximate the behavior of the bilinear realization around the initial augmented lifted states, it might suffer from prediction error. But still, the proposed algorithm has more reliability compared to realizing a linear thermal predictor from the beginning with regard to Remark 2, and the fact that this strategy considers changing the states in the bilinear term at the start of each prediction horizon, which results in higher precision [41]. Indeed, the proposed algorithm retains the reliability of the bilinear realization while leading to a quadratic convex optimization problem that can be solved fast enough to be updated at every time step. 4.4 Control performance metrics The are determined to assess the reliability and effectiveness of the control strategy. The ATV is defined as follows (25) ATV ≜ 1 N s ∑ k = 1 N s | T ( k ) − T ref ( k ) | , where T ( k ) and T ref ( k ) are the actual value and the reference value of the zone temperature at step k , respectively, and N s denotes the total number of samples. In addition, the ESR is defined as follows (26) ESR ≜ Q ̄ ref − Q ̄ Q ̄ ref × 100 , where Q ̄ and Q ̄ ref are the average cooling loads of the target and reference control strategies, respectively. Indeed, this metric determines the percentage of saved cooling load using the target method compare to a reference method. 5 Results and comparison In this section, the network architecture employed to realize the predictive thermal model for the target building is described, followed by the precision evaluation of the model. Moreover, the effectiveness of the proposed control methodology is discussed in detail. In addition, this section presents a set of comparisons between the proposed DBKPC configuration, another supervisory DPC approach called HAVOK-MPC, and the baseline controller. The proposed method can be compared with other approaches in three aspects, including the accuracy of the obtained model, the average thermal violation, and the energy savings ratio. The results of the comparative analysis are summarized in Table 5. 5.1 Predictive thermal model evaluation The collected data for realizing the required model in Problem I includes the zones’ temperatures T A , T B , and T C , the ambient temperature T amb , the control signal of each supply fan U A , U B , and U C , and the SAT of the AHU T AHU . The zones’ temperatures are considered as the target system states, the ambient temperature is assumed to be a known disturbance, and the supply fans’ control signals and the inverse of the SAT denoted by U SAT are considered as the target system inputs. Due to the various magnitude ranges of measurements, data normalization is performed for data preprocessing. The training data has been gathered for 1 month of the summer season, from July 1, at 00:00, to July 31, at 23:59, using the co-simulation of TRNSYS-MATLAB. The final batch consisted of 7440 points sampled with t s = 6 min . The zones’ temperatures and T AHU are maintained using well-tuned PI controllers with the properties provided in Table 2 and different setpoints. These setpoints are considered within the range of 10 20 ∘ C and 15 30 ∘ C for T AHU and zones’ temperatures, respectively. To obtain a reliable predictive thermal model for the understudied office building, a multilayer perceptron with six layers is adopted as the lifting encoder. The encoder consists of an input layer with three neurons, four hidden layers, each with four neurons, and an output layer with one neuron. Also, the rectified linear unit (ReLU) is chosen to be the activation function of each layer. The proposed architecture is developed using PyTorch, and the optimization technique known as adaptive moment estimation (Adam) is employed to train the network parameters. Considering the mentioned structure for the lifting encoder results in a model with an order of 4 . To validate the realized predictive thermal model, test data is collected from another hot month of the year (i.e., August). Fig. 6 displays both the actual temperature and the corresponding bilinear realization for the setpoints of the zone’s temperature from August 20, 0:00, to August 24, 23:00. As illustrated in Fig. 6, this model has the promising potential of predicting the future states of the HVAC system. Using metrics (19) and (20), the CVRMSE values for zones A, B, and C are 9.62%, 19.15%, and 17.23%, respectively. Additionally, the NMBE values for these zones are 1.72%, 3.49%, and 3.12%, respectively. According to ASHRAE Guideline 14 [65], a model’s prediction accuracy can be verified if its CVRMSE and NMBE values are both less than 30% and 10%, respectively. Considering the aforementioned metrics and results, it can be inferred that the realized predictor is reliable and precise. 5.2 Predictive thermal model comparison As previously stated, [35] presented a DPC framework for residential buildings using the Koopman operator and the Hankel alternative view of the Koopman (HAVOK) algorithm. This subsection outlines the superiority of the proposed bilinear model over the realized predictor using the aforementioned HAVOK approach. To this end, the same dataset that is introduced in Section 5.1 is utilized as the training data for the HAVOK approach. Also, the required data preprocessing is applied to it. Further, the same data is generated for test of both predictors. These predictors can be compared in two aspects, including the long-term prediction performance and stability. In terms of prediction reliability, the proposed thermal predictive model has a considerably lower CVRMSE and NMBE, which shows its superior prediction performance. The prediction performance metrics are summarized in Table 3. In addition, as shown in Fig. 7, the obtained model using the HAVOK approach fails to capture the dynamics of T C . Furthermore, the iISS constraint enhances the stability of the proposed bilinear predictor; however, the HAVOK method has a high probability of realizing an unstable model due to the lack of stability constraints. 5.3 DBKPC implementation As previously stated, the proposed hierarchical control scheme includes the supervisory DBKPC and the local-level PI controller. The DBKPC strategy is responsible for generating the fan control signal for individual zones and determining the maximum SAT for the AHU. In addition, the local-level PI controller is tasked with regulating the determined SAT. Further, to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, a three-zone office building is simulated in TRNSYS, and the suggested hierarchical control configuration is implemented using a coupled TRNSYS-MATLAB simulation framework by the Type 155 module. To this end, the DBKPC has a prediction horizon of N p = 240 steps, equivalent to a duration of 24 h. In addition, weighting matrices of the MPC cost function (23) are determined using a trial-and-error method to align with the prioritization of objectives which is outlined in Remark 3. Figs. 8–10 and Table 4 present the evaluation results of the DBKPC for the control and optimization of the multi-zone HVAC system through three scenarios, namely office typical operation, various temperature setpoints, and over occupied office. The aforementioned scenarios and their results are described in the following. Scenario 1 : Office typical operation In this scenario, the temperature setpoint for all three zones is considered to be 22 ∘ C during working hours (7:00 to 18:00) and 26 ∘ C when the office is closed. Fig. 8(a) depicts all measured temperatures, the reference value, and the control signals associated with the fans and chilled water pump. Also, the colored areas represent working hours, i.e., when the office is occupied. As shown in Fig. 8(a), using the proposed controller, the zones’ temperatures perfectly keep tracking the reference value. In addition, as expected respecting Remark 3, the corresponding control signal of zone A, U A is saturated during the cooling operation, which means that the maximization of the SAT is the first priority of the proposed control strategy. In other words, the proposed strategy uses the maximum potential of fans to maintain each zone’s temperature setpoint, and once one of the control signals will be saturated, the SAT of the AHU will be decreased. Moreover, as it can be seen the control signals have not one step significant magnitude change during this scenario. Furthermore, the total amount of the coil’s cooling load is demonstrated in Fig. 8(b), which shows that variation in T AHU heavily affects the value of the cooling load. Scenario 2 : Various temperature setpoints During this scenario, each zone’s temperature has to track various distinct references that are provided in Table 4. The temperatures of the zones and their corresponding reference values are illustrated in Fig. 9(a), and the variation of the Q total and its average is depicted in Fig. 9(b). The results show that the proposed control strategy is capable of maintaining each zone’s temperature at its corresponding reference contrary to the thermal interaction that exists through the adjacent walls. Moreover, the saturation of the U B confirms that in the designed control algorithm the first priority is given to the maximization of the SAT. Therefore, as it can be seen, the T AHU begins to decreasing once the U B reaches the maximum value 100%. Scenario 3 : Over occupied office To ensure the reliability of the proposed controller in dealing with unknown disturbances, altering occupants is considered in this scenario. As illustrated in Fig. 10(a), the office goes through overcrowding during its working hours, spanning from 10:00 to 15:00, in which there are more occupants in each zone. Table 4 shows the internal heat gain resulting from additional occupants. Figs. 10(a) and 10(b) depict the outcomes of the scenario and confirm the proposed method’s disturbance attenuation capability. The value of the ATV provided in Table 4 and the results depicted in Fig. 10(a) show that even with increasing unknown disturbances, the proposed controller has the promising capability to provide indoor thermal comfort. 5.4 Control performance comparison In this subsection, the effectiveness of the mentioned control strategies is discussed. To this end, all three controllers are implemented in TRNSYS-MATLAB co-simulation under the same conditions. The performance of the controllers is evaluated using introduced metrics in Section 4.4. To compare the DBKPC and HAVOK-MPC methods, the same weighting matrices Q , R Δ , and R u are utilized. Fig. 11(a) and Fig. 11(b) show that the DBKPC outperforms the HAVOK-MPC in terms of temperature maintenance and energy savings. Particularly, the DBKPC strategy reduces the cooling coil’s energy consumption by 31.27% compared to the HAVOK-MPC. Besides, the average ATV for three zones using the DBKPC method is 0.5, while it reaches 1.13 for the HAVOK-MPC. The baseline controller, on the other hand, consists of four well-tuned PI controllers for maintaining T A , T B , T C , and T AHU . As they are used independently while the zones have thermal interaction, the tuning procedure is complicated and time-consuming. Moreover, there are multiple options for the desired SAT of the AHU. Clearly, the lower setpoint of T AHU results in better reference tracking. However, there is a trade-off between tracking performance and cooling coil’s energy consumption. Therefore, to compare the proposed control strategy with the baseline controller, T AHU = 18 ∘ C is considered. Fig. 11(a) and Fig. 11(b) and Fig. 12 show that the DBKPC consumes less energy than the baseline controller. In particular, the DBKPC reduces energy consumption by 14.2%. The comparison of controllers’ efficacy is summarized in Table 5 and Fig. 13. Furthermore, the baseline controller with various T AHU is evaluated for the sake of clarity. 6 Discussion The effectiveness of the proposed hierarchical control framework was demonstrated in the previous sections, and the simulation and comparison results showed the significant performance of this approach. However, it is worth noting that the effectiveness of the DBKPC is heavily dependent on the precision of the developed control-oriented predictive model and the design and tuning factors of the control configuration. In this regard, the main control design parameters and their influence on performance are discussed in this section. Besides, the main advantages and limitations of the suggested DPC scheme is discussed. Regarding the primary advantages of DBKPC, they can be summarized as follows: 1. The DBKPC approach is purely data-driven and does not require any prior knowledge regarding system’s principle equations and supervision, despite the expert knowledge that is required for gray-box and white-box methods. 2. This method has the potential to reduce approximately 30% of total cooling energy while ensuring indoor thermal comfort. 3. The developed control-oriented thermal predictor is interpretable and has the same thermal behavior as the target-building in the entire operating region. 4. The required data for training is collected in one month (i.e., July). However, the Koopman operator’s global characteristics result in a realized thermal predictor that is also reliable in other hot months of the year (i.e., June and August). 5. The realized thermal predictor is guaranteed to be iISS by imposing the iISS constraint on the training procedure. 6. The linear approximation of the bilinear predictor within the prediction horizon leads to a convex optimization problem that enables the use of quadprog solver. Indeed, this approach guarantees a solvable optimization problem, even though the actual system being optimized is non-linear. 7. The proposed strategy is extendable to other large-scale HVAC systems. 8. As shown in the previous section, the proposed control strategy is capable of attenuating known and unknown disturbances. However, there are also limitations that should be considered regarding the DBKPC method. As stated before, the control performance of the proposed DPC approach is highly dependent on the control-oriented realized model’s precision. Also, the prediction reliability of the realized predictor would be enhanced by increasing the number of neurons in the lifting encoder’s output layer. Indeed, this is equivalent to increasing the number of observables and results in developing a predictor with a higher dimension, which is not desirable due to the computational demand required in the control algorithm for anticipating the system behavior within the prediction horizon. Consequently, a trade-off has to be established between predictor accuracy and its dimension, which directly affect controller performance and computational demand, respectively. In this study, we attempted to realize a model with minimal dimension and a single neuron in the output layer of the lifting encoder. The quality of the resulting realized predictive model can be affected by a number of tuneable parameters when configuring a network. The number of hidden layers, the number of hidden neurons in the hidden layers, the activation function, and the learning rate are among them. Since there is no established strategy in the literature for optimizing these parameters, we have mostly relied on trial and error similar to the approach outlined in [24]. To this end, several architectures with a single neuron in the lifting encoder’s output layer are considered, and the network is trained for each architecture to determine the optimal model. Also, each architecture is trained with different activation functions, including Sigmoid, Tanh, and ReLU. The realized model’s prediction accuracy is assessed throughout the network architecture trials using the CVRMSE metric, and the optimal model is selected by comparing various predictors based on the CVRMSE and NMBE metrics, and Taylor diagram. Eventually, the model with best prediction performance realized using the architecture [ 3 4 4 4 4 1 ] and ReLU activation function. The predictor comparison based on CVRMSE and NMBE metrics is provided in Table 3 for different activation functions. Moreover, the realized bilinear model is compared to the HAVOK predictor [35], in terms of long-term prediction performance. Fig. 14 depicts the Taylor diagram, and it can be inferred that the realized model using the chosen architecture has significantly superior accuracy compared to the other predictors. On the other hand, since the cost function is multi-objective and minimizing the tracking error and maximizing the SAT of the AHU are conflicting, a trade-off among them has to be made. Therefore, the weighting matrices Q and R u are used to find a balance between weighted goals. In fact, this balance should be adjusted by means of weighting terms to give priority to one of the targets. Here, we determined these terms to prioritize tracking performance by considering large values for diagonal components of matrix Q . Next, we put emphasis on controlling the input rate and avoiding abrupt changes in the control signals using matrix R Δ . In addition, we determined the diagonal components of matrix R u such that maximizing the SAT has a higher priority than minimizing the fans’ control signals. Indeed, the diagonal component of matrix R u associated with U SAT is considered to have a much larger value than its other components. 7 Conclusion This paper presents an advanced strategy for multi-objective optimization of the HVAC operation in multi-zone buildings. To this end, a supervisory control configuration named DBKPC is developed for the energy-efficient operation of multi-zone HVAC systems while maintaining the desired thermal environment for occupants. This method is based on the integration of a supervisory DPC configuration and a bilinear Koopman predictor. The DBKPC approach leverages the potential of DNN to realize a global control-oriented thermal predictive model that enables the application of the proposed supervisory predictive control framework. In addition, to enhance the stability of the realized predictor, the iISS constraint is imposed on the training procedure. Given that the AHU is responsible for a significant proportion of the HVAC energy consumption, this work aims to minimize the cooling load of the AHU by determining the maximum SAT that could provide the desired thermal interior environment while fulfilling thermal comfort. To validate the reliability and capability of the DBKPC method, a three-zone office building is simulated in TRNSYS, and the proposed control configuration is implemented by a coupled TRNSYS-MATLAB simulation framework. The results demonstrate the significant performance of the DBKPC in terms of reliability, model precision, tracking error, and energy conservation. Besides, a comparative study shows that the DBKPC method outperforms the conventional PI controller and another recent supervisory DPC approach named HAVOK. Moreover, the DBKPC strategy could reduce about 30% of total cooling energy with the guarantee of indoor thermal comfort. To further demonstrate the scalability of this method, implementing DBKPC for large-scale HVAC systems and experimental validation of this strategy remains for future work. coredata.dc:description: Predictive control is an effective method for addressing the increasing demand for heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems to operate with greater flexibility and efficiency. In this paper, the multi-objective problem of energy-efficient HVAC operation while tracking desired setpoints is addressed through an advanced control strategy, including a novel supervisory data-driven predictive control (DPC) and a local loop with a PI controller. The supervisory level is based on the integration of the DPC framework and the bilinear Koopman predictor. A deep neural network architecture is developed to realize the bilinear building thermal predictor. In addition, the integral input-to-state stability (iISS) constraint is enforced in the training procedure to obtain a global iISS control-oriented thermal predictor that enables the application of predictive control purely based on historical data. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated through the simulation of a three-zone office in the transient system simulation software (TRNSYS). The proposed control configuration is implemented using a coupled TRNSYS-MATLAB simulation framework. It has shown significant potential for keeping the desired environment in line with energy conservation. Furthermore, a comparison is conducted between the proposed approach, the conventional controller, and another recent DPC approach, which demonstrates the suggested method’s superiority.
coredata.dc:title: Multi-objective optimization of building HVAC operation: Advanced strategy using Koopman predictive control and deep learning
